The State of Hate

We traveled the country, this is what we found.

 

The Virginian Cocktails

The Virginian Cocktails in Twentynine Palms, Califonia is located on the corner of 29 Palms Highway and Cholla Avenue. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Kari Wilson

Kari Wilson, 26, is a bartender at The Virginian Cocktails in Twentynine Palms, California.


Laurette Rogers and Wedda Warrick

Laurette (left) and Wedda have been drinking partners for close to three years.


 

Gus's Fresh Jerky

The first of Gus’s Fresh Jerky stores in Olancha, California, started in an old gas station in 1996. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Nora Berguem

She’s a sociology major at Whittier College in Whittier, Calif. She spends her summers working at Gus’s Fresh Jerky as a cashier.


 

Manzanar National Historic Site

Moved to Manzanar National Historic Site in late 2002, the restored mess halls are the same type as those used by Japanese-Americans interned at Manzanar during World War II. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Elizabeth and Terry Vance

Elizabeth and Terry Vance have been divorced for more than 20 years, but they still travel together. A recent trip brought them to Manzanar Historic Site.


Mina Monden

Mina Monden visited the Manzanar Historic Site with her nephews, who were traveling from Japan.


Bernadette Johnson

Bernadette Johnson is the superintendent of the National Park Service at Manzanar.


 

Bishop, California


 

Virginia City, Nevada

Originally a boomtown built in the 1850s, Virginia City was built around mining silver and gold from the Comstock Lode that was discovered in the area. In the late 1870s the mines’ outputs decreased and the town’s population suffered. In recent year, it’s managed to survive as a tourist town. (Jim Tuttle/News21)


Wayne Douglas Tarrant

 We’re bringing in too many different races. We have too much diversity. Other countries don’t open their border like we do, but now we’re in trouble with Muslims. We don’t really have a problem (with racism) up here. The only time we have problem is when we have some Arabs up here in their dress. They’re in full burka and people get very nervous. They don’t know if they have explosives underneath those outfits. All the merchants up here get nervous. There is a lot of people up here with guns and they’re standing at the ready in case there is a problem. It’s not fear, we’re fearless… I think it’s politics causing the problems. The politicians are causing the problems because of greed. 


Paul Coombes

 I come from an ethnic family. My daughter, Zoe, is half African-American, so I am very sensitive to the topic of hate. I think all races have a lot of work to do. It’s better than it used to be, but we have a long way to go. 

 

Stagecoach, Nevada

The gas station in Stagecoach, Nevada, where we found Brian Baldwin. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Brian Baldwin

Brian Baldwin was stocking produce at a gas station in Lyon County, Nevada when News21 met him. He said people are too 'politically sensitive' today, and recalled a time when America was 'pretty cool for a while there.'


 
 

Salt Lake City, Utah


Michelle Calwley

 I think we’re going backwards. Totally backwards, when a large majority of us just want to be together. We’re all the same. 


Bradley DeNorris

 When you have something like that, where the president is saying there is blame on both sides, equivocating about straight up racism sides, then I think it gives people more license to be straight out racist.  


Lisa Corsetti

 I am not going to fly the American flag on the fourth of July, instead I am going to fly my resistance flag because I believe that this country needs to go forward not backwards. We don't want open borders, we just want people to be treated fairly and not cruelly when they come here. You know I think America the beautiful is what we should strive for and it should be both beautiful inside and out. 


Martin Turner IV

 The right number of Americans voted for Donald Trump to win the election because they need a change from Hillary Clinton was getting ready to deliver upon them. Every race causes problems for America. There are laws to keep civil order. If we don’t have civil order, our social order breaks down. So it’s not just the illegal immigrants that cause it a lot of problems. 


 

Little America Hotel, Wyoming

Located off of Exit 68 on Interstate 80, Little America is a combination of hotel, gas station, and gift shop. It was intentionally built in a remote location to act as a haven for westward-bound travelers. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Mike and Tirzah Smith

Mike, a technician from Orem, Utah, and his wife Tirzah, a second grade teacher, are returning from a pioneer trek to Martin’s cove with their youth group.


 

Laramie, Wyoming

Matt Mcomie (left) prepares for a game of pool with Kevin Farris (center left) while Kraig Smith and Buck Ward (right) converse at the the Buckhorn Bar & Parlor in Laramie, Wyoming. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Buck Ward

 Hate and friction is everywhere around us. Even here in the bar, we disagree about politics. I think Trump is a big (expletive). He’s out of touch with America and what Americans want. It’s the things he’s saying and not saying that is spurring hate. 


Fred Lee

 The media is making things a bigger deal than they are. Everything becomes more heightened when the media can reach millions of people on their phones. 


Logan Lee

 Being an interracial couple, [Fred and I] see the race thing. Talking about it and hyping it up makes it worse for us. People have made comments to us, but it’s a lot better in Wyoming... Here, there isn’t the history of racial tensions. 


 
 

Mount Rushmore


Jeff & Janet Smith

 There’s definitely friction and I think sixty percent of our friction is the news. We show all bad and no positive because there are as many positive people in the country as there are negative. —Jeff 


Charles & Gale Smith

 “So I think the media has the Trump effect. It’s their fault. And people criticize Trump for tweeting, but it’s the only way he can reach the American people because the media won’t report what he is doing accurately.” —Charles

“These presidents would agree with a lot of the policies that he’s adapted. I think that most of Americans are behind the president and what he is doing.” —Gale 


 

The Corn Palace

With an exterior decorated using corn ears, The World’s Only Corn Palace in Mitchell, South Dakota, attracts around half a million people a year. The exterior murals change every year with a different theme. For 2017, the theme was “South Dakota Weather”. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Lauren and Devon Langston

Lauren and Devon from Virginia are traveling the country in an RV.


 
 

Tekamah, Nebraska

With a slogan of “Looking to the Future”, Tekamah, NE is a small town of 1,852 people northwest of Omaha.  (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Frankie McCandless and Keith Terwilliger

Frankie(left) and Keith are construction workers in town from Tennessee on a job.


Larry Bucy

A Tekamah native who served in the U.S. Army from 1969 to 1973


 
 

Perry, Iowa


Laurie Haynes

 I am proud of what America was founded to be. I am not very proud of what it is right now. 


Debra Allen

 I mean it’s just a people aren’t talking to each other and not trying to get along. You just got to weigh both sides. And you got to look and not make an opinion right away. You got to think about it and listen to both sides. 


Jerry Roberts

 I think that we are rapidly approaching the precipice. We haven’t approached or taught this generation or even past generations how to sit down and discuss things and how to work problems through. I think it’s a problem solving situation. And everyone just has their view point and they are not willing to sit down and aren’t willing to participate in discourse. I’m a veteran, so I will feel pride in America. I don’t know what others feel. Sometimes they don’t know enough to stand up and take their hat off when the flag goes by, but at least they show up for the event and that’s a starting point. 


Connie Metzler

 And then the media will take on something bad that happened and just continually talk about it over and over and over and over and over and over, to where it will get a group of people upset and angry. 

 

Mustachio's Bar and Grill

In a village that hasn’t grown or shrunk since it’s founding in the late 1800s, Mustachio’s Bar and Grill is one of two food establishments in Carbon Hill. (Lenny Martinez Dominguez/News21)


Diane Eartly

 There's no like 'I hate you and don't come in here' type thing where they're going to fight in the middle... I know you probably have the diverse people that don't get along and especially with politics or something... they'll just be quieter or they'll just leave. 


Stephanie Long

 There’s a lot of growing that needs to be done, but I’m hoping [America] will get better. 


 
 

Fremont, Ohio

Built between 1859 and 1865, this 31-room mansion on the Spiegel Grove estate in Fremont, Ohio was home to America's 19th president, Rutherford B. Hayes. (Jim Tuttle/News21)


Chandra Palm & Julie Bellfy

Fremont native Chandra(left) and her friend Julie belive social meida contributes to the divisiveness in America today.

Omelet Shoppe

The Omelet Shoppe is a 24-hour diner lcoated near Interstate 64 in Beckley, West Virginia. The diner is a poplar attraction for local residents. Beckley native George Bailey said he has been getting his morning cup of coffee at the diner for the past three years. (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Felicia Robertson

Felicia Robertson is a waitress at the Omelet Shoppe.


William Bailey

William has been visiting the Omelet Shoppe every day for the past three years.


A woman was murdered at the Travelodge Hotel in Beckley, West Virginia on July 9. Felicia Robertson, a waitress at the Omelete Shoppe next door, attributes the murder to one cause — drugs. The opiod epidemic grips the community of 17,000. (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Brandy’s Catfish and Trout Pond

Tristan 'Turtle' Hylton, of Beckley, attempts to reel in his pole at Brandy's Catfish and Trout Pond while Leah J. King, Jayden Farnsworth, and Uriah Farnsworth congregate around him awaiting what they hope is a big catch. (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Jessica Vance

Jessica Vance, of Beckely, enjoys bonding with her children over fishing at Brandy's Catfish Pond near Bolt, West Virginia.

Van Buren, Arkansas

Van Buren, Arkansas is home to a population of 24,000. The Main Street district (pictured) is a popular attraction for tourists who visit the community to take rides on the excursion trains. (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Couple in Van Buren

Elk City, Oklahoma

Elk City, OK is located on the west side of the state along Route 66. The city recorded a population of 11,555 in 2017. Stout & Son Pawn Shop (pictured) was started in 1952 by Steve Stout's grandfather.  (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Larry Parvin

Larry Parvin is the Pastor at Main Street Baptist Church in Elk City, Oklahoma.


Steve Stout

Steve owns Stout and Son Pawn Shop in Elk City

 

Amarillo, Texas

@@Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.@@ (Jim Tuttle/News21)


Boozefighter Whiff

Boozefighter Whiff (his biker name) is a psychology professor and has worked in academia for 30 years.


 

Albuquerque, New Mexico

@@Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.@@ (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Maya Vigil

Maya is a college student at the University of New Mexico and and a waitress at Central Grill in Albuquerque, New Mexico. She believes open conversation is the solution to the tensions that exist in America.


 

Grants, New Mexico

Riverwalk Park is located in Grants, New Mexico along Route 66. Grants is home to a population of approximately 9,000 citizens. (Tilly Marlatt/News21)


Melanie Beyale

Melanie Beyale, 23, is a member of the Navajo Nation and fearful of the state of the nation.


Stone Gonzales

Stone Gonzales works at the New Mexico Mining Museum and feels that both Democrats and Republicans want change.
